The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned lots about policy around addiction and harm reduction.
I appreciate the knowledge I gained from my final project, whose topic I got to choose.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: gives a very broad overview of addiction policy, current issues, and history in the united states. Interdisciplinary student group.
Weakness: didn't feel very highly organized

Strengths: We got to choose the final project. Professor Sindelar and Jingyuan always offered make time for office hours, which was great.
Weaknesses: Honestly, many. I would not recommend taking this class. Professor Sindelar used EXTREMELY stigmatizing language to describe individuals with alcohol misuse issues and individuals who are overweight. She also used statistics from the early-2000s---extremely outdated and not helpful. Classes were always lecture, so there was no point in doing the readings, because she never let students talk. Jingyuan also never gave feedback on the weekly assignments, so we never knew how to improve/get a higher grade. This was a pretty useless class, which is sad because so many students are interested in these topics and this class is hosted at YSPH.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are interested in economic policy in response to public health issues. However, as not everyone in this course is an Economics student, it can be a bit repetitive when mentioning economic concepts and is certainly not rigorous economically.

No. I would not recommend taking this class. Professor Sindelar used EXTREMELY stigmatizing language to describe individuals with alcohol misuse issues and individuals who are overweight. She also used statistics from the early-2000s---extremely outdated and not helpful. Classes were always lecture, so there was no point in doing the readings, because she never let students talk. Jingyuan also never gave feedback on the weekly assignments, so we never knew how to improve/get a higher grade. This was a pretty useless class, which is sad because so many students are interested in these topics and this class is hosted at YSPH.
